ygData.subject: Re: [rest-discuss] URI always a URL?
ygData.msgSnippet: I reckon this is now correct: URI = URL (resolvable e.g. http://... that you can type into a browser) and URN ( urn:... ). The identifiers in RDF, namespaces

I reckon this is now correct:
URI =3D URL (resolvable e.g. "http://..." tha=
t you can type into a browser) and URN ("urn:...").
The identifiers in RDF,=
 namespaces that look just like a URL and that are called URI's (or URL's) =
are in fact just strings that follow the format of URLs.

Seem reasonable?
=

Sean.

To: "Sean Kennedy" <seandkennedy@...>

yahoogroups.com>
Date: Friday, 9 July, 2010, 15:51

On Fri, Jul 9, 2010 at =
5:23 AM, Sean Kennedy <seandkennedy@...> wrote:

















Hi=
 Eric,
=A0=A0=A0 Thanks for that. Is this correct : the string e.g. "http:/=
/www.example.org/somepath", when used as an identifier for resources e.g. R=
DF or for identifying namespaces, is in fact a URN (and thus a URI) because=
 it is not a location that one would type into a browser (dereference)?



=
=A0I could be mistaken, but I thought the format of a URN was different tha=
n a URL, thus a URL used as a name is not a URN, but it is strictly a URI. =
(Wikipedia reference=A0for URN schema.)


Ryan Riley=A0
